Posts.Content: Hi eliza44  my Dcis was not seen on mammogram, neither was my small invasive, nor on uss or mri. I had a mastectomy, no recon. Surgeons are reluctant to remove healthy breast however many women have had a contralateral mastectomy (removal of healthy breast) because of genetic reasons or for symmetry. You are entitled to have your ‘good’ Breast removed for symmetry under Nice guidelines as I understand it. You usually need a psychologist report. There is a closed Facebook group called flat friends for women who are not having recon or considering it.... you may find it helpful regarding your decision making. xx
Posts.Title: DOUBLE or SINGLE or not at all

Posts.Content: Hi Addison  I was diagnosed March 21st (IDC) and my mammogram  at my initial referral appointment was reported as normal  even though there was a cancer ( I was a self referral). I had a routine mammogram last year reported as normal.   It does say in the information about mammogram that it’s not 100% and that’s why we need to be breast aware which you certainly were and are are now going to have treatment.  Choices are individual but you were given one so that is a good thing. Whatever choices we make are done for the right reasons with the information we have. You’ll get a lot more info post surgery with your results  it is a scary time. There’s a lot of the unknown, the waiting and anxiety/fear, interrupted sleep.... I started a diary, I find meditation  helps with anxiety, I try to be positive, I’ve had my meltdown moments and I try and keep occupied . Youll get a lot of support/ information on here and there is the Breast cancer care site but you will be told to keep off Dr Google as there’s a lot of rubbish out there. Xhugx

Posts.Content: Thanks Eddiboy I think going for DIEP is such a big decision just because of the surgery involved but it seems to give a more natural result and will change with weight gain/loss so you will definitely get the results you are looking for. I want to minimise surgery, have quick recovery so my gut feeling was no recon....flap surgery is definitely not for me. I’m not very keen on having an implant either just not sure what it would be like, feel like and am conscious of the fact that it will need replacing at some time ... that’ll take me well into my 70’s if I’m looking at max 15year life span of implant. If I go no recon I’m hoping I’ll adapt as well as I have following both recent surgeries where I have already lost nipple area and my small boob has become even smaller and an odd shape... still, the decision making process is giving me a headache and like you say I’ll have to talk it through I’ll write my list out of pros and cons but it’s all down to feelings and at the minute I’m going round in circles a bit... sorry for rambling on. I hope you mind settled during the night, + your hot flashes cooled down a bit, enough for you to get a bit of sleep. Hope your pre op assessment goes ok. You’ll be away on your lovely holiday soon so you’ll probably do a lot of walking then. I’m intending to get out lots and get a bit fitter pre op... need to lose more weight and try and get rid of spare tyre. xhugsx

Posts.Content: Hi yellowroses . As you’re having a local anaesthetic you will be well numb. I remember my surgeon put a lot of local in when I had my lumpectomy. Although I had a GA the local worked the same. Wear a soft bra 24/7 for support and comfort post op. I did take paracetamol/ibuprofen regularly for at least a few days then just the paracetamol and used the Brufen  to top up as required for up to a week. Posts.Title: Breast Cancer spread to Lymph Nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Baduki1 Im in the same situation having been told last week, after wle then re excision, that I will need mastectomy. I had the options put to me, have the reading material, have the bcn appointment next week and have asked questions/ had input/ read threads on here to gain some insight of pros/cons/adapting/experience etc etc.  It’s a lot to take in especially when dealing with diagnosis at the same time...it’s actually caused me a huge amount of stress thinking about it especially as I feel it’s expected of me to automatically go for recon.  Im aware I’ll be getting more results after mx and Im naturally cautious about it.  I know at this moment what I don’t want and that is a huge op with all it implies, I’m not keen on having an implant for lots of reasons. I do believe implants work better if having bilateral as they “match”.  I don’t really want to have further surgery in the future if I can help it  (unless of course it’s to save my life for example) .... there may be complications and sometimes there are other procedures to complete the process or to get the best possible results of the recon....I think that will depend on an individuals expectations. Implants usually have to be replaced  sometime although I’ve heard of a few still going after 20+ yrs. Not having recon and waiting may be my best option as Im no where near being 100% for it and many have said that if there’s any doubts wait. I’ve had really positive input from women from age 40’s to 70’s who have no recon and are living happy, active lives. We are all individuals and will make different decisions for different reasons.  Whatever decision you make will be right for you xhugsx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Choices....Any Thoughts?

Posts.Content: Sending hugs Leolady56 xx
Posts.Title: Shout out to lovely Leolady56

Posts.Content: RoseKen1 there is a group called Flat Friends on Facebook. All the women are living flat, that is have not had recon, or are waiting for recon after mx, or have been deconstructed and living flat. You may find it helpful, supportive and can join the closed group if you so wish. Xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi RoseKen1 I had to make the same decision as you after I’d had a lumpectomy and re excision. I’m 63. . Having to decide about recon confused the issue for me and I became really quite stressed over it in spite of thinking that no recon would be the best option for me.  I did get input from lovely women on here and after weighing up the pros and cons, writing them down, I had a mastectomy, no recon 3 months ago.  My OH was fully supportive. I am happy with my decision. In some ways I prefer my flat side. It is odd at first but I got used to it really quick. The scar will fade over time. It’s easy to examine the area too.   I went out the day after my op and felt confident and not self conscious. I used a front fastening soft bra and a softie and dressed looked my usual self. I do go out ‘flat’ as well, in fact I didn’t notice I was flat one day until after I’d been out, round a supermarket and walking around town....I don’t think anyone noticed and even when I realised I wasn’t phased at all.  Good luck with your decision and future surgery. Whatever you decide will be right for you.  Hugs xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: RoseKen1 ..It isn’t an easy decision but once made you feel much more settled. I was so undecided I put off surgery for a week...and I’d already had 5 weeks of going into ostrich mode (surgeon on hols at that time). I’ve not had rads or chemo but I’m quite happy to answer questions about mastectomy and afterwards, on here or via pm. There is lots of support on here and it’s great you are going to a support night locally.  Hugs xx

Posts.Content: RoseKen1 I’m happy to be messaged. It must be difficult with youngsters but you are right to be open, in language they understand. There are books especially for children from MacMillan. I hope you get a date soon.  Xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi peterawake My first op was lumpectomy and snb . I had micromet less than 0.5 mm in sentinel node. The other 2 nodes taken were clear. I was told micromet is classed as negative node and this was confirmed when I phoned the helpline on this site. I eventually had a mastectomy and a further node taken was clear as was an intermammary node. I’ve had no other treatment.. no rads/chemo and I’m on Letrozole.
